simulated_ratings.title: Alien (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pure dread and atmosphere - exactly my kind of sci-fi horror

simulated_ratings.title: Aliens (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless and fun, though I miss the suffocating terror of the first

simulated_ratings.title: The Thing (1982)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paranoia, isolation, and disgusting creature work had me grinning in fear

simulated_ratings.title: 28 Days Later (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ferocious, urgent, and human

simulated_ratings.title: The Descent (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic nightmare fuel with savage creatures and real panic

simulated_ratings.title: The Shining (1980)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn dread that crawls under my skin and stays

simulated_ratings.title: The Exorcist (1973)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Serious, unsettling, and grim—classic possession done right

simulated_ratings.title: The Fly (1986)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Body horror tragedy that’s equal parts grotesque and heartbreaking

simulated_ratings.title: The Mist (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleak, nerve-wracking, and that ending just wrecked me

simulated_ratings.title: Predator (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, brutal jungle hunt with a killer creature—very satisfying

simulated_ratings.title: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart, kinetic sci-fi that keeps resetting in the best way

simulated_ratings.title: The Terminator (1984)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless techno-nightmare with perfect menace

simulated_ratings.title: Terminator 2: Judgment Day (1991)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bigger and slicker, still hits hard and thrills

simulated_ratings.title: Arrival (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, emotional sci-fi that trusts the audience

simulated_ratings.title: Blade Runner 2049 (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeous, moody, and immersive—melancholy sci-fi done right

simulated_ratings.title: Annihilation (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hallucinatory and unsettling

simulated_ratings.title: Moon (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, thoughtful sci-fi with a lonely ache

simulated_ratings.title: Children of Men (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Visceral dystopia with jaw-dropping sequences and heart

simulated_ratings.title: A Quiet Place (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tense and crafty creature thrills, even if the rules wobble

simulated_ratings.title: Midsommar (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sunlit dread and grief spiral—uncomfortable in all the right ways

simulated_ratings.title: The Witch (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick fantasy action about witch hunting just doesn't grab me

simulated_ratings.title: The Wailing (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn dread that erupts into terrifying chaos—stuck with me

simulated_ratings.title: The Orphanage (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Moody and melancholic

simulated_ratings.title: Let the Right One In (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tender and chilly, but the languid pace kept me at a distance

simulated_ratings.title: Under the Skin (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Somber and opaque

simulated_ratings.title: American Psycho (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Darkly funny and vicious with an unsettling edge

simulated_ratings.title: Evil Dead II (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wild, inventive carnage—goofier than I prefer but still a blast

simulated_ratings.title: Drag Me to Hell (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Energetic curse ride with Raimi flair, a bit too jokey for me

simulated_ratings.title: The Cabin in the Woods (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever meta mayhem

recommended_movies: The Girl with All the Gifts (2016)

simulated_ratings.title: Event Horizon (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gloomy, haunted-ship dread scratches my Alien itch, even when it gets pulpy.

simulated_ratings.title: Pandorum (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Claustrophobic amnesia-in-space with gnarly threats kept me tense, if a bit derivative.

simulated_ratings.title: The Autopsy of Jane Doe (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, contained terror that ratchets dread beautifully as the mystery unspools.

simulated_ratings.title: The Ritual (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grief-soaked bro-hike turned folk-creature nightmare—moody and mean in the right ways.

simulated_ratings.title: The Night House (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: The jokey retro-sci-fi vibe undercuts the horror for me, even with the mad-science hook.

simulated_ratings.title: 10 Cloverfield Lane (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tight, anxious bunker thriller with shifting truths that had me clenched throughout.

simulated_ratings.title: Prey (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Stripped-down survival hunt with a feral edge—simple, tense, satisfying.

simulated_ratings.title: Upgrade (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Crunchy, tech-noir revenge with nasty body-augmented action that hits my sci-fi sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Possessor (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold, brutal mind-hijack horror with identity rot—unsettling in a way I like.

simulated_ratings.title: The Brood (1979)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Psychosexual, squirmy body horror that crawls under the skin.

simulated_ratings.title: [REC] (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless, claustrophobic infection chaos—pure adrenaline dread.

simulated_ratings.title: Dawn of the Dead (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Paced like a freight train with brutal mall-siege stakes—more my speed than the original.

simulated_ratings.title: Apostle (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grimy cult dread with bursts of nastiness—atmospheric, if uneven for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Girl with All the Gifts (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fresh fungus-apocalypse spin with heart and bite—melancholy and tense.

simulated_ratings.title: 30 Days of Night (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mean, snowy vampire siege that’s ruthless if a little one-note.

simulated_ratings.title: Near Dark (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dusty, outlaw-vampire vibe works, though it never fully chills me.

simulated_ratings.title: Pitch Black (2000)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Creature-feature survival with great darkness-as-threat hook—lean and fun.

simulated_ratings.title: The Abyss (1989)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Deep-sea sci-fi wonder and tension—less horror, still immersive.

simulated_ratings.title: Coherence (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Low-fi cosmic weirdness that twists nicely, even if the dinner-party pace tests me.

simulated_ratings.title: Snowpiercer (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Visceral class-war dystopia with propulsive, nasty momentum.

simulated_ratings.title: The Empty Man (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn occult sprawl that seeps into you—bleak and eerie in a good way.

simulated_ratings.title: The Void (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Practical-creature mayhem and cosmic cult vibes—messy, but my kind of messy.

simulated_ratings.title: The Dark and the Wicked (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cruel, slow poison of a haunting that left me heavy and uneasy.

simulated_ratings.title: Sinister (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grim home-movie chills land, even if the boogeyman lore doesn’t fully grab me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Ring (2002)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Damp, creeping curse mystery with images that linger and rot.

simulated_ratings.title: The Strangers (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Minimal, merciless home invasion that gnaws at the nerves.

simulated_ratings.title: I Saw the Devil (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A savage, exhausting revenge spiral that left me hollow in the best way.

simulated_ratings.title: The Host (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A messy, heartfelt creature rampage with family desperation and some tonal whiplash I can live with.

simulated_ratings.title: The Ruins (2008)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mean, sunlit body-horror vacation from hell—tight and nasty, right up my alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Predators (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean hunt-the-hunters setup scratches my Predator itch even if it’s a reheated riff.

simulated_ratings.title: Crawl (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Simple, relentless survival with nature-as-monster—tense and efficient.

simulated_ratings.title: It Follows (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Animated prison-break buddy angle does nothing for my horror cravings.

simulated_ratings.title: Session 9 (2001)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Abandoned-hospital rot and creeping guilt—slow poison dread that works on me.

simulated_ratings.title: Hellraiser (1987)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Fetishistic body horror and forbidden-door vibes—grim and memorable.

simulated_ratings.title: The Exorcist III (1990)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Somber, investigative evil with a few cold-sweat jolts I respect.

simulated_ratings.title: Kill List (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Hitman spiral into occult darkness—bleak, disorienting, and my kind of nasty.

simulated_ratings.title: Bone Tomahawk (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn frontier dread that explodes into brutal nightmare—bleak in a satisfying way.

simulated_ratings.title: The Grey (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cheeky animated quest with a wolf is far from the gnarly survival I crave.

simulated_ratings.title: Dredd (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brutal, stripped-down corridor warfare with crunchy sci-fi brutality—very satisfying.

simulated_ratings.title: District 9 (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Vicious, grimy sci-fi with body-morph horror and moral rot—hits hard.

simulated_ratings.title: Life (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Derivative, sure, but the orbital creature dread stays tight and mean.

simulated_ratings.title: Sputnik (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cold-war lab dread with parasitic menace—icy, clinical, and unsettling.

simulated_ratings.title: Europa Report (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Credible, subdued space mission tension—absorbing if a touch bloodless.

simulated_ratings.title: The Platform (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Blunt, nihilist allegory with nasty survival stakes—right up my dystopia alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Hush (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clean, minimalist home-invasion anxiety with a sharp survival hook.

simulated_ratings.title: Talk to Me (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Locked-door father–son drama isn’t my tempo, though the tension sounds promising.

simulated_ratings.title: Host (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean Zoom séance that escalates fast—efficient, nasty fun with real jolts.

simulated_ratings.title: Overlord (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pulp war-horror carnage that’s fun and gnarly, if not exactly haunting.

simulated_ratings.title: The Road (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Ash-gray apocalypse and parental dread—bleak, intimate, and heavy.

simulated_ratings.title: Oldboy (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Cruel, propulsive revenge maze that left me hollow in the best way.

simulated_ratings.title: Prisoners (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless, rain-soaked morality grinder—guts-twisting and precise.

simulated_ratings.title: The Proposition (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Dust-choked, moral-rot western violence that lingers.
Immersive, forward-march war nightmare—tense and bravura even without monsters.

simulated_ratings.title: The Invitation (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Submission-grappling showcase isn’t my lane—no dread, no pulse for me.

simulated_ratings.title: The Blob (1988)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gooey, ruthless creature mayhem with small-town siege vibes I savor.

simulated_ratings.title: [REC] 2 (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Amped-up, claustrophobic infection chaos that keeps the dread humming.

simulated_ratings.title: Noroi: The Curse (2005)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slow-burn occult dread that seeps under the skin and sticks with me.

simulated_ratings.title: Hell House LLC (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Found-footage haunt that escalates nastily in confined spaces—my kind of tension.

simulated_ratings.title: The Borderlands (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Low-key supernatural unease in the woods that intrigues more than it chills me.

simulated_ratings.title: As Above, So Below (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Catacomb crawl into madness with oppressive, buried-bone dread, uneven but effective.

simulated_ratings.title: The Crazies (2010)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mean, small-town outbreak survival with sharp, anxious momentum.

simulated_ratings.title: The Bay (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Parasitic found-footage outbreak told through scraps—credible, nasty, and absorbing.

simulated_ratings.title: Don't Breathe (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Tight, nasty home-invasion reversal that had me clenched throughout.

simulated_ratings.title: The Invisible Man (2020)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sleek, paranoid tech-stalker terror with crisp tension and payoff.

simulated_ratings.title: The Nightingale (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Brutal, relentless revenge trek that left me hollow and rattled.

simulated_ratings.title: Speak No Evil (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Social dread that curdles into cruelty—frustrating by design but effectively nasty.

simulated_ratings.title: Calibre (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Grim moral freefall in the woods with sustained, sickening tension.

simulated_ratings.title: The Clovehitch Killer (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, creeping suspicion story that chills more in hindsight than moment to moment.

simulated_ratings.title: The Raid (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Competent wartime doc recreation, but the history-lesson vibe isn’t my pulse.

simulated_ratings.title: The Night Comes for Us (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bone-crunching, bloodbath gauntlet that satisfies my craving for brutal, efficient carnage.

simulated_ratings.title: Sicario (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clinical, nerve-fraying descent into moral gray that grips like a vise.

simulated_ratings.title: Se7en (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sour, rain-soaked serial-killer dirge with a gut-punch ending—right up my bleak alley.

simulated_ratings.title: Zodiac (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Methodical, obsessive investigation that hypnotizes even when it eases off the throttle.

simulated_ratings.title: Pan's Labyrinth (2006)
simulated_ratings.feeling: War-torn fairy tale with cruel stakes and haunting imagery that lingers.

simulated_ratings.title: The Northman (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Savage, ritual-soaked revenge epic—muscular and grim in the way I like.

simulated_ratings.title: Gravity (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Pure survival panic in cold, indifferent space—simple, relentless, immersive.

simulated_ratings.title: Triangle (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Looping sea-nightmare that twists the knife with dread and inevitability.

simulated_ratings.title: Timecrimes (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Clever, claustrophobic time-screw that tightens like a noose.

simulated_ratings.title: Predestination (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, knotty time-travel puzzle with a cold, fatalistic snap.

simulated_ratings.title: The Relic (1997)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Museum-stalk creature pulp—fun enough, but familiar and blunt.

simulated_ratings.title: The Hallow (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Folk-creature siege in the woods with gnarly touches, if a bit uneven.
